transcript.text: Do you look after plants? Do you make
green waste? Then you need to make
compost. I'm here to introduce you with
not one but two brand new accelerated
composting machines. The leaders. No
more waiting for up to 12 months for
mature compost.
>> I can't wait that long.
>> The leader can reduce that time to one
month. No more paying for fertilizer.
You'll have all the plant food you need.
No more spreading disease and weeds
around the garden. No more rats, birds,
or cockroaches. It's too hot for them.
Ouch.
No more monitoring temperature and
moisture. This machine regulates that
for you. No more stinky compost. Those
smells are filtered out with carbon
filters. No more ugly bins or piles in
around the garden. Yuck. These neat
units hang on your wall. Lids are
accessible and there is space for a
wheelbarrow underneath. No more
backbreaking turning the compost. It all
gets mixed by the leader. No more
shoveling into the wheelbarrow. This
machine loads your wheelbarrow.
The best part is when you compost,
you'll be helping reduce greenhouse gas
emissions. But how does it work? I hear
you asking. Here's the clever bit. The
microbes do the work. We're just
providing a happy home for them to live
in. To do that, we give them fresh air.
We keep them warm.
We feed them.
Here we have the continuous and the
batch leaders.
The batch leader produces a premium
quality compost that has been allowed to
mature. The batch leader has three
levels. the active, the curing, and the
harvest level. In the active phase,
there are three bins for the user to
drop compost into. When the user has
finished in putting what they needed to
into the vessel, the user starts the
program. The vessel is then locked. The
compost heat builds up and then when it
drops back below 40Â° C, the bins tip
compost into the next level for the
curing phase. The lid is unlocked and
the bin is ready to be reloaded. The
curing phase here, the compost will be
topped up by the active vessels until it
is full. Once full, the active vessels
will start tipping into the alternate
curing vessel. Once the alternate curing
vessel is also full, the first vessel
tips into the harvest level. The at the
harvest level, the compost is ready to
be used.
It can be stored in this space where it
will continue to mature like a fine
wine. The continuous leader is a simpler
design, but has the potential for the
mature and the immature compost to mix.
The lid on the continuous composter
isn't locked, so the user can add little
bits when they like. It works by using a
labyrinth. The new compost added applies
downward pressure in the first cell.
When the mixer rotates, the pressure is
equalized and the compost is pushed into
the next vessel. This is the way that
material is pushed from cell to cell
through the labyrinth. The labyrinth
slows down the flow from start to
finish, which reduces the amount of
immature compost being mixed with the
mature compost. Slowing the flow lets
the immature compost build up heat. As
the compost decays, it also reduces
volume. In this continuous process,
there isn't any empty space created by
the decay. The material gets pushed
along and eventually moves to the end of
the process. The user can then harvest
the most mature compost by turning the
orre at the bottom of the machine. With
the batch leader, you choose higher
quality. With the continuous leader, you
choose a smaller footprint and a more
intuitive experience. With leader,
you'll have rich soil and healthy plants
in no time.
